newsitem.title: JAPAN: AAMA's Card says concerned at yen's weakness - Jiji.
newsitem.headline: AAMA's Card says concerned at yen's weakness - Jiji.

text.p: Andrew Card, president of the American Automobile Manufacturers Association (AAMA), said he was very concerned about the dollar's rise above 125 yen, a Japanese news agency reported on Tuesday.
Jiji also quoted Card as saying that the leaders of the Big Three U.S. carmakers will mention currency levels at a meeting with President Bill Clinton.
"I am very troubled that the yen is weakening even further and I think it is especially of concern that it has broken through the 125 yen threshold," he was quoted as saying.
"I would suspect one of the issues that will be raised (by the Big Three executives) in that meeting (with President Clinton) will be the excessively weak yen," he added.

Card also told Jiji in an interview that the yen's weakness was due to concern about the prospects for the Japanese economy, following a rise in Japan's consumption tax, and expansion in the U.S. economy.
"This is a yen problem, not a dollar problem," he was quoted as saying.
He said that Japan needs to open its markets further and stimulate domestic demand, adding that Japan and the United States should take steps to prevent the yen from falling further.
"This is likely to invite increased trade friction," he said.
A date for the meeting between the Big Three leaders and President Clinton has not yet been set, he said.
